pullRequest.body:
In this PR, we define the module length to be the krull dimension of the lattice of submodules and prove that it is additive in short exact sequences. Relies on #22069, #22036 and #21869

---

`+ map_lt_map_of_ker_inf_eq`
`+ map_lt_map_or`
`+ map_mono_of_ker_inter_eq`
`+ ne_map_or_ne_kernel_inter_of_lt`

`+ rel_of_le`
`+ ssubset_iff_exists`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#22036~~
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#22069
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#21869
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

I'm not entirely sure about this approach. I think we should show that the length is equal to the length of a composition series and then this result is immediate, instead of developing a whole new API reproving Jordan-Holder.

> I'm not entirely sure about this approach. I think we should show that the length is equal to the length of a composition series and then this result is immediate, instead of developing a whole new API reproving Jordan-Holder.

So I do agree that this is a lot of API to develop for this task (though I admit I can't yet see how what's proven here would imply Jordan Holder without some more work). We considered using this Jordan-Holder proof at one point, but we went for this other one because we thought on paper it looked like not much more work and that it would give the case for infinite length modules for free. But I agree that this small advantage over the Jordan-Holder based proof is definitely not worth all this API development.

That said, I still think the API itself is worthwhile for reasoning about chains of submodules because it makes moving them around with maps easier. I could be wrong about this applicability of the API because of my lack of experience, but if it is the case that this API is independently useful then I think it's less clear cut which approach to the proof we should use, because the actual proof of the main theorem here is fairly short once all the other stuff is built up.

> I think we should show that the length is equal to the length of a composition series

I agree this is basic API for Module.length and should be added to this PR.

The approach I am suggesting is [here](https://gist.github.com/erdOne/c167a05741189ca7ecae6d803f71faaa).
The main objection to your approach is I don't really see any other application of trimmed length besides this. @chrisflav has strong opinions on `RelSeries` in general. Maybe he can chime in?

> The approach I am suggesting is [here](https://gist.github.com/erdOne/c167a05741189ca7ecae6d803f71faaa). The main objection to your approach is I don't really see any other application of trimmed length besides this. @chrisflav has strong opinions on `RelSeries` in general. Maybe he can chime in?

Cool, yeah this is definitely a very nice approach and I agree that whatever path we take this stuff relating the length to the length of a composition series needs to be in there. I can't think of any good examples, but I think our approach could be useful in arguments where you have some chain of submodules and you want to take the image of this under a homomorphism, which may in general turn this into a Relseries with \leq. Then this api could be nice to have to think of the underlying chain of this image. This, I feel, turns up from time to time, though admittedly I don't do this kind of argument very often.

> The approach I am suggesting is [here](https://gist.github.com/erdOne/c167a05741189ca7ecae6d803f71faaa).

I agree that we want at least everything of this up to `Module.length_compositionSeries`.

> The main objection to your approach is I don't really see any other application of trimmed length besides this. @chrisflav has strong opinions on `RelSeries` in general. Maybe he can chime in?

I can see a use-case for an API for strengthening (and weakening) the `r` in `RelSeries r`. A similar thing happens in Andrews `LTSeries.exists_relSeries_covBy`. The "trimmed length wrt. to a stronger relation `s`" would then be the length of the strengthening wrt. `s`. (`r` should here be the reflexive closure of `s`). This gives you some more leg room for pushing a `RelSeries` forward or backward when the map only preserves `s` but not `r`. In any case, this should probably not be developed for `<` but rather for a general pair `r`, `s` as above.
Sure. Let's try to merge this then. Hopefully the connection to composition series and `IsFiniteLength` could be done in some future PR.
Well, the relation with `IsFiniteLength` has already been proved at #22356 (the only required theorem is the quotient module version of the additivity of length)

**[lint-style (comment with "bot fix style" to have the bot commit all style suggestions)]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Â· let n' : Fin (rs.length) := {val := n, isLt := by rw[o]; exact lt_add_one n} ```

```suggestion
    rs.trimmedLength â‰¤ Module.length R M := by
```

```suggestion
    Module.length R M = Module.length R N + Module.length R (M â§¸ N) := by
```
Please recheck indentation everywhere. Almost every declaration in this PR has one or more indentation issues.

```suggestion
  by_cases q : ker f âŠ“ A â‰  ker f âŠ“ B
  Â· exact Or.inr q
  Â· simp only [ne_eq, not_not] at q
    apply Or.inl
    intro h
    apply hab.ne
    apply le_antisymm hab.le
    intro x hx
    obtain âŸ¨z, hz, hzyâŸ© := (h â–¸ âŸ¨x, hx, rflâŸ© : f x âˆˆ Submodule.map f A)
    suffices x - z âˆˆ LinearMap.ker f âŠ“ A by simpa using add_mem this.2 hz
    exact q â–¸ âŸ¨by simp[hzy], sub_mem hx (hab.le hz)âŸ©
```

```suggestion
  lt_iff_le_and_ne.mpr âŸ¨inf_le_inf le_rfl hab.le,
   Or.elim (LinearMap.ne_map_or_ne_kernel_inter_of_lt f hab)
    (fun h â†¦ False.elim (h q)) (fun h â†¦ h)âŸ©
```
`fun h â†¦ h` could be `id` probably?

```suggestion
  lt_iff_le_and_ne.mpr âŸ¨Set.image_mono hab.le,
   Or.elim (LinearMap.ne_map_or_ne_kernel_inter_of_lt f hab)
    (fun h â†¦ h) (fun h â†¦ False.elim (h q))âŸ©
```

```suggestion
    {i j : Fin (x.length + 1)} (h : i â‰¤ j) : r (x i) (x j) :=
```

I see that you're using `strictMono_inf_prod_sup` in `map_lt_map_or`. I think we should probably break this down into: (1) provide a version of [strictMono_inf_prod_sup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/ModularLattice.html#strictMono_inf_prod_sup) that uses `Iic z` and `Ici z`, (2) show the Krull dimensions of `Iic z` and `Ici z` are equal to the lengths of the submodule and the quotient module, (3) show the Krull dimension of a product order is exactly the sum of the Krull dimensions, and (4) show in general that the Krull dimension of an order is no less than the sum of the Krull dimensions of `Iic z` and `Ici z`.

Please ensure that you insert a space between a tactic and its arguments
```suggestion
      simp [CategoryTheory.ShortComplex.moduleCat_exact_iff]
```
Please do not start a line with `:`.
I think we should make `Module.length` take value in `â„•âˆž` using `WithBot.unbot` (`unbotD` is also acceptable).

pullRequest.title: draft(Module): Module length is additive in short exact sequences

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Order/KrullDimension): some lemmas relating `Order.height`, `Order.coheight` and `krullDim`
